title: Covenant Curse and Exile
objective: Trace covenant disobedience to exile consequence

required_passages.text: For so it was, that the children of Israel had sinned against the LORD their God, which had brought them up out of the land of Egypt, from under the hand of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and had feared other gods, And walked in the statutes of the heathen, whom the LORD cast out from before the children of Israel, and of the kings of Israel, which they had made. And the children of Israel did secretly those things that were not right against the LORD their God, and they built them high places in all their cities, from the tower of the watchmen to the fenced city. And they set them up images and groves in every high hill, and under every green tree: And there they burnt incense in all the high places, as did the heathen whom the LORD carried away before them; and wrought wicked things to provoke the LORD to anger: For they served idols, whereof the LORD had said unto them, Ye shall not do this thing. Yet the LORD testified against Israel, and against Judah, by all the prophets, and by all the seers, saying, Turn ye from your evil ways, and keep my commandments and my statutes, according to all the law which I commanded your fathers, and which I sent to you by my servants the prophets. Notwithstanding they would not hear, but hardened their necks, like to the neck of their fathers that did not believe in the LORD their God. And they rejected his statutes, and his covenant that he made with their fathers, and his testimonies which he testified against them; and they followed vanity, and became vain, and went after the heathen that were round about them, concerning whom the LORD had charged them, that they should not do like them. And they left all the commandments of the LORD their God, and made them molten images, even two calves, and made a grove, and worshipped all the host of heaven, and served Baal. And they caused their sons and their daughters to pass through the fire, and used divination and enchantments, and sold themselves to do evil in the sight of the LORD, to provoke him to anger. Therefore the LORD was very angry with Israel, and removed them out of his sight: there was none left but the tribe of Judah only.

Israel experiences persistent covenant violation. Prophets warn of judgment. Exile to Assyria follows northern kingdom disobedience. Babylonian exile follows southern kingdom violation. Exile is covenant curse.
Exile fulfills covenant curse predicted for disobedience. Forced removal from land is ultimate judgment. Loss of temple marks rupture in covenant worship. Yet exile is not final separation.
Key themes: exile is covenant curse for persistent disobedience. God permits destruction but remains faithful. Exile purges unfaithfulness. Judgment serves redemptive purpose.
What is the primary consequence of covenant disobedience?
This completes lesson twenty-one. You studied covenant curse and exile. Next lesson examines prophetic hope in restoration.

vocabulary.definition: Forced removal from land as covenant curse for sustained disobedience to God
Deportation of Judah to Babylon in 586 BCE following covenant violation and temple destruction

study_notes: Exile demonstrates covenant as dynamic relationship with real consequences. It is not the end of covenant but purging judgment leading to restoration.
